name: Lucero
description:
'''Lucero Hogaza León{{efn|Pronounced {{IPA|es|luˈseɾo}}}}''' (born 29 August 1969) is a Mexican singer, actress, and television personality. Dubbed "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|the Americas' Bride]]",{{notetag|In [[Spanish-speaking countries]], "América" means all of the [[Americas]], both [[North America|North]] and [[South America|South]]. Lucero's nickname, "La novia de América", uses this broader meaning, not just the United States.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Staff |first=Billboard |date=2015-10-02 |title=Lucero to Host First Edition of Latin American Music Awards |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/latin/lucero-host-latin-american-music-awards-6714617/ |access-date=2025-06-23 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref>}} she is known for her influence in [[Latin music]] and [[Television in Latin America|Latin American television]], with a career spanning over four decades. She started her career at age 10 as a [[child actress]] on [[Televisa]] shows like ''[[Alegrías De Mediodía|Alegrías de Mediodía]]'', ''[[Chiquilladas]]'', and later starred in ''[[Chispita (TV series)|Chispita]]''. In 1982, she debuted as a singer with [[Él (album)|''Él'']] and soon became one of the most popular [[teen pop]] stars of the 1980s. Her albums from that time include ''[[Un Pedacito de Mí]]'' (1986), ''[[Ocho Quince]]'' (1988), and ''[[Cuéntame (Lucerito album)|Cuéntame]]'' (1989).

During the 1990s, she starred in successful telenovelas like ''[[Cuando llega el amor|Cuando Llega el Amor]]'' (1990), ''[[Los Parientes Pobres]]'' (1993), and ''[[Lazos de Amor]]'' (1996). At the same time, she released Latin pop albums like ''[[Sólo Pienso en Ti (Lucero album)|Sólo Pienso en Ti]]'' and ''[[Piel de Ángel]]''. She also became known for singing [[Ranchera|ranchera music]], with albums such as ''[[Lucero de México]]'' (1992) and ''[[Cariño de Mis Cariños]]'' (1994). Lucero voiced [[Jane Porter (Tarzan)|Jane]] in the [[Spanish language in the Americas|Spanish]]-version of Disney's ''[[Tarzan (1999 film)|Tarzan]]'' (1999) and sang the Spanish version of "[[Reflection (song)|Reflection]]" for ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998). From 1997 to 2004, she was the host of ''[[Teletón (Mexico)|Teletón México]]'', one of the country's biggest charity TV events.

In the 21st century, she released more albums, like ''[[Mi destino|Mi Destino]]'' (2000) and ''[[Quiéreme Tal Como Soy]]'' (2006). She starred in hit telenovelas such as ''[[Mi Destino Eres Tú]]'' (2000), ''[[Alborada (TV series)|Alborada]]'' (2005), and ''[[Soy tu dueña|Soy tu Dueña]]'' (2010). Lucero also hosted the [[Latin Grammy Awards]] between 2006 and 2013 and the first two [[Latin American Music Awards]]. In 2011, she became a coach on the first season of the singing show ''[[La Voz (Mexican TV series)|La Voz]]''. Lucero is considered one of the [[List of best-selling Latin music artists|best-selling Latin artists]], with over 16 million records sold worldwide. She has won many awards, including a [[Billboard Latin Music Awards|''Billboard'' Latin Music Award]] and 21 [[Premios TVyNovelas]], more than any other artist. She also received special honors like the 'Leaders in Spanish-language [[Emmy Awards|Emmy Award]]' and the [[Hispanic Television Summit]]'s Outstanding Achievement Award. In 2025, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named Lucero one of the greatest female Latin pop artists of all time.
